content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Strategically choosing {R}

Here is the reasoning: In this game, both choices have the potential for higher payoffs compared to each other when playing against different opponent choices (R beats B and vice versa). However, since the payoff for both choices is greater when the opponent chooses R, it makes sense to choose R as your strategy, even though the payoff for both choices is lower when both players choose R. To maximize your earnings in 75 rounds, you would want to get into as many situations where your opponent chooses R and you both receive 45$ each round. This reasoning assumes that the player is rational and wants to earn the most money possible over the course of the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.
